senses.sense: Expressing distance or motion.
(now obsolete or dialectal) From (of distance, direction), "off".
(obsolete except in phrases) Since, from (a given time, earlier state etc.).
From, away from (a position, number, distance etc.).
examples: There are no shops within twenty miles of the cottage.

senses.sense: Expressing separation.
Indicating removal, absence or separation, with the action indicated by a transitive verb and the quality or substance by a grammatical object.
examples: Finally she was relieved of the burden of caring for her sick husband.

senses.sense: Indicating removal, absence or separation, with resulting state indicated by an adjective.
examples: He seemed devoid of human feelings.

senses.sense: (obsolete) Indicating removal, absence or separation, construed with an intransitive verb.
Expressing origin.
Indicating an ancestral source or origin of descent.
examples: The word is believed to be of Japanese origin.

senses.sense: Introducing an epithet that indicates a birthplace, residence, dominion, or other place associated with the individual.
examples: Jesus of Nazareth (after hometown)
Anselm of Canterbury (after diocese)
Anselm of Aosta (after birthplace)
Anselm of Bec (after monastery)
Pedro II of Brazil (after dominion)
Mrs Miggins of Gasworks Road, Mudchester (after place of residence)

senses.sense: Indicating a (non-physical) source of action or emotion; introducing a cause, instigation; from, out of, as an expression of.
examples: The invention was born of necessity.

senses.sense: (following an intransitive verb) Indicates the source or cause of the verb.
examples: It is said that she died of a broken heart.

senses.sense: (following an adjective) Indicates the subject or cause of the adjective.
examples: I am tired of all this nonsense.

senses.sense: Expressing agency.
(following a passive verb) Indicates the agent (for most verbs, now usually expressed with by).
examples: I am not particularly enamoured of this idea.

senses.sense: Used to introduce the "subjective genitive"; following a noun to form the head of a postmodifying noun phrase.
examples: The contract can be terminated at any time with the agreement of both parties.

senses.sense: (following an adjective) Used to indicate the agent of something described by the adjective.
examples: It was very brave of you to speak out like that.

senses.sense: Expressing composition, substance.
(after a verb expressing construction, making etc.) Used to indicate the material or substance used.
examples: Many 'corks' are now actually made of plastic.

senses.sense: (directly following a noun) Used to indicate the material of the just-mentioned object.
examples: She wore a dress of silk.

senses.sense: Indicating the composition of a given collective or quantitative noun.
examples: What a lot of nonsense!

senses.sense: Used to link a given class of things with a specific example of that class.
examples: Welcome to the historic town of Harwich.

senses.sense: Links two nouns in near-apposition, with the first qualifying the second; "which is also".
examples: I'm not driving this wreck of a car.

senses.sense: Introducing subject matter.
Links an intransitive verb, or a transitive verb and its subject (especially verbs to do with thinking, feeling, expressing etc.), with its subject-matter; concerning, with regard to.
examples: I'm always thinking of you.

senses.sense: (following a noun (now chiefly nouns of knowledge, communication etc.)) Introduces its subject matter; about, concerning.
examples: He told us the story of his journey to India.

senses.sense: (following an adjective) Introduces its subject matter.
examples: This behaviour is typical of teenagers.

senses.sense: Having partitive effect.
(following a number or other quantitive word) Introduces the whole for which is indicated only the specified part or segment; "from among".
examples: Most of these apples are rotten.

senses.sense: (following a noun) Indicates a given part.
(now archaic, literary, with preceding partitive word assumed, or as a predicate after to be) Some, an amount of, one of.
examples: On the whole, they seem to be of the decent sort.

senses.sense: Links to a genitive noun or possessive pronoun, with partitive effect (though now often merged with possessive senses, below).
examples: He is a friend of mine.

senses.sense: Expressing possession.
Belonging to, existing in, or taking place in a given location, place or time. Compare "origin" senses, above.
examples: He was perhaps the most famous scientist of the twentieth century.

senses.sense: Belonging to (a place) through having title, ownership or control over it.
examples: The owner of the nightclub was arrested.

senses.sense: Belonging to (someone or something) as something they possess or have as a characteristic; the "possessive genitive". (With abstract nouns, this intersects with the subjective genitive, above under "agency" senses.)
examples: Keep the handle of the saucepan away from the flames.

senses.sense: Forming the "objective genitive".
Follows an agent noun, verbal noun or noun of action.
examples: She had a profound distrust of the police.

senses.sense: Expressing qualities or characteristics.
(archaic or literary) Links an adjective with a noun or noun phrase to form a quasi-adverbial qualifier; in respect to, as regards.
examples: My companion seemed affable and easy of manner.

senses.sense: Indicates a quality or characteristic; "characterized by".
examples: Pooh was said to be a bear of very little brain.

senses.sense: Indicates quantity, age, price, etc.
examples: We have been paying interest at a rate of 10%.

senses.sense: (US, informal, considered incorrect by some) Used to link singular indefinite nouns (preceded by the indefinite article) and attributive adjectives modified by certain common adverbs of degree.
examples: It's not that big of a deal.

senses.sense: Expressing a point in time.
(chiefly regional) During the course of (a set period of time, day of the week etc.), now specifically with implied repetition or regularity.
examples: Of an evening, we would often go for a stroll along the river.

senses.sense: (UK, dialectal, chiefly in the negative) For (a given length of time).
examples: I’ve not tekken her out of a goodly long while.

senses.sense: (after a noun) Indicates duration of a state, activity etc.
examples: After a delay of three hours, the plane finally took off.

senses.sense: (chiefly US) Denotes the number of minutes before the hour;Before (the hour); to.
examples: I’ll be ready at ten of two ― I’ll be ready at 1:50
What's the time? / Nearly a quarter of three.

senses.sense: (informal) Often used without the hour
examples: I’ll be ready at ten of ― I’ll be ready at 1:50, or 2:50, or whatever time ending in 10 makes most sense in context.

senses.sense: (usually in modal perfect constructions) Eye dialect spelling of have or ’ve, chiefly in depictions of colloquial speech.
(stenoscript) Abbreviation of off, often
(US, ethnic slur, slang) A white person.
(US, ethnic slur, slang) White; white-skinned.
plural of ofay
Alternative form of oh for
In a direction away from the speaker or other reference point.
examples: He drove off in a cloud of smoke.

senses.sense: Into a state of non-operation or non-existence.
examples: Please switch off the light when you leave.
die off

senses.sense: So as to remove or separate, or be removed or separated.
examples: He bit off the end of the carrot.
Some branches were sawn off.

senses.sense: (theatre) Offstage.
examples: noises off

senses.sense: Used in various other ways specific to individual idiomatic phrases, e.g. bring off, show off, put off, tell off, etc. See the entry for the individual phrase.
Inoperative, disabled.
examples: All the lights are off.

senses.sense: Cancelled; not happening.
examples: The party's off because the hostess is sick.

senses.sense: Not fitted; not being worn.
examples: Your feet will feel better once those tight boots are off.
The drink spilled out of the bottle because the top was off.

senses.sense: Rancid, rotten, gone bad.
examples: This milk is off!

senses.sense: (by extension, AU, slang) Disgusting, repulsive, abhorrent.
Less than normal, in temperament or in result.
examples: sales are off this quarter

senses.sense: Inappropriate; untoward.
examples: I felt that his comments were a bit off.

senses.sense: (in phrases such as 'well off', 'poorly off', etc., and in 'how?' questions) Circumstanced.
examples: Our family used to be well off; now we're very badly off.
How are you off for milk? Shall I get you some more from the shop?

senses.sense: Started on the way.
examples: off to see the wizard
And they're off! Whatsmyname takes an early lead, with Remember The Mane behind by a nose.

senses.sense: Far; off to the side.
examples: He took me down the corridor and into an off room.
the off horse or ox in a team, in distinction from the nigh or near horse

senses.sense: Designating a time when one is not strictly attentive to business or affairs, or is absent from a post, and, hence, a time when affairs are not urgent.
examples: He took an off day for fishing.  an off year in politics; the off season

senses.sense: (in phrases such as 'off day') Designating a time when one is not performing to the best of one's abilities.
(of a dish on a menu) Presently unavailable.
examples: — I'll have the chicken please.
— Sorry, chicken's off today.

senses.sense: (British, in relation to a vehicle) On the side furthest from the kerb (the right-hand side if one drives on the left).
examples: The off front wheel came loose.

senses.sense: (cricket) In, or towards the half of the field away from the batsman's legs; the right side for a right-handed batsman.
Not positioned upon, or away from a position upon.
examples: He's off the roof now.
I took it off the table.
Keep off the grass.

senses.sense: Detached, separated, excluded or disconnected from; away from a position of attachment or connection to.
examples: The phone is off the hook
The coat fell off the peg.
He was thrown off the team for cheating.
We've been off the grid for three days now.
We're off their radar.
He's off the computer, but he's still on the phone.

senses.sense: Used to indicate the location or direction of one thing relative to another, implying adjacency or accessibility via.
examples: His office is off this corridor on the right.
We're just off the main road.
Look! There's a UFO off our left wing!

senses.sense: Used to express location at sea relative to land or mainland.
examples: The island is 23 miles off the cape.

senses.sense: Removed or subtracted from.
examples: There's 20% off the list price.

senses.sense: No longer wanting or taking.
examples: He's been off his feed since Tuesday.
He's off his meds again.

senses.sense: (colloquial, more properly 'from') Out of the possession of.
examples: He didn't buy it off him. He stole it off him.

senses.sense: Placed after a number (of products or parts, as if a unit), in commerce or engineering.
examples: Tantalum bar 6 off 3/8" Dia × 12" — Atom, Great Britain Atomic Energy Authority, 1972
samples submitted … 12 off Thermistors type 1K3A531 … — BSI test report for shock and vibration testing, 2000
I'd like to re-order those printer cartridges, let's say 5-off.

senses.sense: (transitive, slang) To kill.
(transitive, Singapore, Philippines) To switch off.
examples: Can you off the light?

senses.sense: (usually in phrases such as 'from the off', 'at the off', etc.) Beginning; starting point.
examples: He has been very obviously an untrustworthy narrator right from the off.

senses.sense: The internal organs of an animal, used as food.
A by-product of the grain milling process, which may include bran, husks, etc.
A dead body; carrion.
That which is thrown away as worthless or unfit for use; refuse; rubbish.
(archaic) offal
plural of offal
(music) The beats not normally accented in a measure.
examples: The congregation clapped along on the offbeat.

senses.sense: (slang) An unconventional person, someone who does not follow the beat, who chooses not to conform.
Unusual; unconventional; not ordinary.
examples: He has such an offbeat sense of humor that hardly anyone finds his jokes amusing.

senses.sense: plural of offbeat
(transitive) to cast off; shed.
(transitive, theatre, television) to remove from the cast of a production.
That which is rejected as useless.
plural of offcast
That which comes off or the act or process of coming off; emission.
The way any thing or business turns out; the way a person comes off from an encounter or enterprise; result; outcome; reception.
(UK, dialectal, chiefly Scotland) An apology; excuse.
(UK, dialectal, chiefly Scotland) An escape or evasion by subterfuge or pretext; a way of avoiding or getting out of a difficult or uncomfortable situation.
An exhibition of temper.
(transitive) To cut off.
A piece that has been cut off of a larger piece when not needed; surplus.
Cut off.
Excess; surplus.
simple past tense and past participle of off
British, Australian, New Zealand and Canadian standard spelling of offense.
Alternative form of offenseless
Alternative form of offenselessly
plural of offence
(transitive) To hurt the feelings of; to displease; to make angry; to insult.
examples: Your accusations offend me deeply.

senses.sense: (intransitive) To feel or become offended; to take insult.
examples: Don't worry. I don't offend easily.

senses.sense: (transitive) To physically harm, pain.
examples: Strong light offends the eye.

senses.sense: (transitive) To annoy, cause discomfort or resent.
examples: Physically enjoyable frivolity can still offend the conscience

senses.sense: (intransitive) To sin, transgress divine law or moral rules.
(transitive) To transgress or violate a law or moral requirement.
(obsolete, transitive, archaic, biblical) To cause to stumble; to cause to sin or to fall.
Capable of being offended.
An offender.
simple past tense and past participle of offend
In an offended manner.
The state or quality of being offended.
One who gives or causes offense, or does something wrong.
A person who commits an offense against the law, a lawbreaker.
plural of offender
present participle of offend
The act of committing an offence.
Responsible; to be blamed.
examples: Something in the fridge smelled terrible. The offending article was soon identified and removed.

senses.sense: A woman who offends.
third-person singular simple present indicative form of offend
The act of offending.
A crime or sin.
An affront, injury, or insult.
The state of being offended or displeased; anger; displeasure.
(team sports) A strategy and tactics employed when in position to score; contrasted with defense.
(team sports) The portion of a team dedicated to scoring when in position to do so; contrasted with defense.
Causing offense; displeasing.
examples: an offenseful act

senses.sense: Unoffending; innocent; inoffensive; harmless.
In an offenseless manner.
Absence of offense.
plural of offense
(obsolete) That may give offense.
(obsolete) Assault; attack, offensive; offense.
Causing offense; arousing a visceral reaction of disgust, anger, hatred, or indignation.
examples: Some people find pornography offensive.
An offensive smell.

senses.sense: Relating to an offense or attack, as opposed to defensive.
examples: The army's offensive capabilities. An offensive weapon.

senses.sense: (sports) Having to do with play directed at scoring.
examples: The offensive coordinator is responsible for ordering all rushing plays.

senses.sense: (countable, military) An attack.
examples: The Marines today launched a major offensive.

senses.sense: (uncountable) The posture of attacking or being able to attack.
examples: He took the offensive in the press, accusing his opponent of corruption.

senses.sense: In an offensive manner.
The quality of being offensive.
plural of offensive
A proposal that has been made.
examples: What's in his offer?
I decline your offer to contract.

senses.sense: Something put forth, bid, proffered or tendered.
examples: His offer was $3.50 per share.

senses.sense: (legal) An invitation to enter into a binding contract communicated to another party which contains terms sufficiently definite to create an enforceable contract if the other party accepts the invitation.
examples: His first letter was not a real offer, but an attempt to determine interest.

senses.sense: (intransitive) To propose or express one's willingness (to do something).
examples: She offered to help with her homework.

senses.sense: (transitive) To present in words; to proffer; to make a proposal of; to suggest.
examples: Everybody offered an opinion.

senses.sense: (transitive) To place at someone’s disposal; to present (something) to be either accepted or turned down.
examples: He offered use of his car for the week.  He offered his good will for the Councilman's vote.

senses.sense: (transitive) To present (something) to God or gods as a gesture of worship, or for a sacrifice.
(transitive, engineering) To place (something) in a position where it can be added to an existing mechanical assembly.
(transitive) To bid, as a price, reward, or wages.
examples: I offered twenty dollars for it. The company is offering a salary of £30,000 a year.

senses.sense: (intransitive) To happen, to present itself.
(obsolete) To make an attempt; typically used with at.
(transitive) To put in opposition to; to manifest in an offensive or defensive way; to threaten.
examples: to offer violence to somebody
The peasants offered no resistance as they were rounded up.

senses.sense: (used in combinations from phrasal verbs) agent noun of off
Capable of being offered; suitable or worthy to be offered.
simple past tense and past participle of offer
One to whom an offer is made.
examples: A unilateral contract consists of a promise on the part of the offeror and performance of the requisite terms by the offeree.

senses.sense: One who offers.
examples: The offerer must wait to learn if the offeree accepts the offer or rejects it.

senses.sense: plural of offerer
gerund of offer
The act by which something is offered.
That which has been offered; a sacrifice.
An oblation or presentation made as a religious act.
A contribution given at a religious service.
Something put forth, bid, proffered or tendered, such as for sale
present participle of offer
plural of offering
One who makes an offer to another.
examples: A unilateral contract consists of a promise on the part of the offeror and performance of the requisite terms by the offeree.
Acceptance of the offer terminates the power of revocation that the offeror ordinarily has.

senses.sense: Someone who presents something to another for acceptance or rejection.
plural of offeror
plural of offer
third-person singular simple present indicative form of offer
Relating to an offering, or the ritual of offertory.
plural of offertory
(Christianity) A prayer said or sung as an anthem while offerings of bread and wine are placed on the altar during the Roman Catholic Mass or the Anglican Communion service.
(Christianity) The part of the Eucharist service when offerings of bread and wine are placed on the altar and when any collection is taken; also, the money or other things collected.
(Christianity, historical) A linen or silken cloth anciently used in various ceremonies connected with the administration of the Eucharist.
Without planning or thinking ahead.
examples: She gave an offhand speech.

senses.sense: Careless; without sufficient thought or consideration.
examples: He doesn't realise how hurtful his offhand remarks can be.

senses.sense: Curt, abrupt, unfriendly.
examples: She was quite offhand with me yesterday.

senses.sense: Right away, immediately, without thinking about it.
In an offhand (a) manner.
in a casual or curt style, without preparation or thought; Impromptu, offhand.
in an offhand manner
the property of being offhand
examples: Your offhandedness is completely inappropriate in such an important situation.

senses.sense: (religion) A ceremonial duty or service, particularly:
(Christianity) The authorized form of ceremonial worship of a church.
(Christianity) Any special liturgy, as the Office for the Dead or of the Virgin.
(Christianity) A daily service without the eucharist.
(Catholicism) The daily service of the breviary, the liturgy for each canonical hour, including psalms, collects, and lessons.
examples: In the Latin rite, all bishops, priests, and transitional deacons are obliged to recite the Divine Office daily.

senses.sense: (Protestant) Various prayers used with modification as a morning or evening service.
(Christianity) Last rites.
(Christianity, obsolete) Mass, (particularly) the introit sung at its beginning.
A position of responsibility.
examples: When the office of Secretary of State is vacant, its duties fall upon an official within the department.

senses.sense: Official position, particularly high employment within government; tenure in such a position.
examples: She held office as secretary of state until she left office to run for office.

senses.sense: A duty, particularly owing to one's position or station; a charge, trust, or role; (obsolete, rare) moral duty.
(archaic) Function: anything typically done by or expected of something.
(now usually in plural) A service, a kindness.
examples: The secretary prevailed at the negotiations through the good offices of the Freedonian ambassador.

senses.sense: (figuratively, slang) Inside information.
A room, set of rooms, or building used for non-manual work, particularly:
examples: The office of the Secretary of State is cleaned when it is vacant.

senses.sense: A room, set of rooms, or building used for administration and bookkeeping.
A room, set of rooms, or building used for selling services or tickets to the public.
(chiefly US, medical) A room, set of rooms, or building used for consultation and diagnosis, but not surgery or other major procedures.
(figuratively) The staff of such places.
examples: The whole office was there... well, except you, of course.

senses.sense: (figuratively, in large organizations) The administrative departments housed in such places, particularly:
examples: He's from our public relations office.

senses.sense: (UK, AU, usually capitalized, with clarifying modifier) A ministry or other department of government.
examples: The secretary of state's British colleague heads the Foreign and Commonwealth Office.

senses.sense: (Catholicism, usually capitalized) Short for Holy Office: the court of final appeal in cases of heresy.
A particular place of business of a larger white-collar business.
examples: He worked as the receptionist at the Akron office.

senses.sense: (now in the plural, dated) The parts of a house or estate devoted to manual work and storage, as the kitchen, scullery, laundry, stables, etc., particularly (euphemism, dated) a house or estate's facilities for urination and defecation: outhouses or lavatories.
(UK law, historical) Clipping of inquest of office: an inquest undertaken on occasions when the Crown claimed the right of possession to land or property.
(obsolete) A piece of land used for hunting; the area of land overseen by a gamekeeper.
(figuratively, slang, obsolete) A hangout: a place where one is normally found.
(UK military slang, dated) A plane's cockpit, particularly an observer's cockpit.
(computing) A collection of business software typically including a word processor and spreadsheet and slideshow programs.
(obsolete) An official or group of officials; (figuratively) a personification of officeholders.
(obsolete) A bodily function, (particularly) urination and defecation; an act of urination or defecation.
(obsolete) The performance of a duty; an instance of performing a duty.
To provide (someone) with an office.
(intransitive) To have an office.
A person who holds an office, especially one appointed or elected to a public office; an incumbent
plural of officeholder
Without an office (room or building where business is carried out).
Operating business with a permanent remote work approach and no need for offices.
examples: officeless company
officeless future

senses.sense: Alternative spelling of office mate
One who has a position of authority in a hierarchical organization, especially in military, police or government organizations.
A respectful term of address for an officer, especially a police officer.
One who holds a public office.
An agent or servant imparted with the ability, to some degree, to act on initiative.
(colloquial, military) A commissioned officer.
(transitive) To supply with officers.
(transitive) To command as or like an officer.
simple past tense and past participle of officer
(archaic or humorous, rare) A female officer.
The role or status of an officer.
Of or relating to officers.
present participle of officer
The attitudes and behaviour of an officer.
Without an officer.
plural of officer
The position or role of an officer.
plural of office
third-person singular simple present indicative form of office
Of or pertaining to an office or public trust.
examples: official duties

senses.sense: Derived from the proper office or officer, or from the proper authority; made or communicated by virtue of authority
examples: an official statement or report

senses.sense: Approved by authority; authorized.
examples: The Official Strategy Guide

senses.sense: (Of a statement) Dubious but recognized by authorities as truth and/or canon.
examples: Despite these testimonies, "accidental asphyxiation" remains his official cause of death.

senses.sense: (pharmaceutical) Sanctioned by the pharmacopoeia; appointed to be used in medicine; officinal.
examples: an official drug or preparation

senses.sense: Discharging an office or function.
Relating to an office; especially, to a subordinate executive officer or attendant.
Relating to an ecclesiastical judge appointed by a bishop, chapter, archdeacon, etc., with charge of the spiritual jurisdiction.
(slang) True, real, beyond doubt.
examples: Well, it's official: you lost your mind!

senses.sense: (pharmacology) Listed in a national pharmacopeia.
An office holder, a person holding an official position in government, sports, or other organization.
examples: Officials in the Firefly administration assure the Sylvanians they don't want war either.
In most soccer games, there are three officials: the referee and two linesmen.
The company's officials became nabobs as it took on more and more power after Plassey.

senses.sense: The people elected to government or employed in the civil service.
The typical language of officials or official documents; legalistic and pompous language.
Alternative spelling of officialization
The rigid, perfunctory and literal adherence to official duties and regulations
Officials collectively
plural of officiality
The charge, office, court, or jurisdiction of an official.
The ecclesiastical charge, office, court, or jurisdiction of an official principal.
The state or fact of being official.
Officials collectively.
The process or result of officializing.
(transitive) To make official.
simple past tense and past participle of officialize
present participle of officialize
In an official manner; according to official rules or regulations.
(slang) Thoroughly, completely.
examples: That’s it! I’m officially outraged.

senses.sense: plural of official
Alternative form of officiality
A person who officiates at a religious ceremony (other than the Eucharist)
A person who officiates at a civil (non-religious) wedding ceremony.
plural of officiant
Of or pertaining to an office or an officer; official.
(historical) A Scottish land division, part of a large estate.
(intransitive, transitive) To perform the functions of some office.
examples: She officiated as registrar at the wedding.
She officiated the wedding as registrar.

senses.sense: (intransitive, transitive, sports) To serve as umpire or referee.
examples: This is the second time he has officiated at a cup-final.
He's never officiated a cup-final before.

senses.sense: A person appointed to office

third-person singular simple present indicative form of officiate
present participle of officiate.
The act of officiating.
A person who officiates.
Medicinal.
(obsolete, rare) Used in a shop, or belonging to it.

In officinal terms.

Offensively intrusive or interfering in offering advice and services.
in an officious manner

In an offish manner.

A pipe to drain or let off water.

Of a system, currently not connected (generally electrically) to a larger network. For example, a power plant which is not connected to the grid, or a computer which is not connected to the Internet or to any other communications service.
examples: I saved the web pages so I could read them later offline.

senses.sense: (by extension) Happening in the physical world (the real world) as opposed to on the internet.
examples: offline meetings
offline dating

senses.sense: While offline; with an offline system.
(business slang) Outside the current meeting, in a more private setting.
From ("off") the Internet
examples: I stole the images offline

senses.sense: (computing, transitive) To take (a system, etc.) offline; to demote from an active or online state.
(transitive) to unload.
(transitive) to get rid of things, work, or problems by passing them on to someone or something else.
examples: He offloaded the defective car onto an unsuspecting buyer.

senses.sense: (transitive, rugby) to pass the ball.
(transitive, aviation, travel) to deny a person on a standby list due to lack of space.

(transitive, aviation, travel) to change a passengers' ticket status from "checked in" to "open", allowing further changes. (This applies regardless of whether the passenger has boarded the aircraft or not).
The act of offloading something, or diverting it elsewhere.
(rugby) The act of passing the ball to a team mate when tackled.

present participle of offload
The act by which something is offloaded.

A reproduction of a single article from a journal or similar publication.
examples: I got a lot of requests for offprints of my paper on cold fusion.

senses.sense: (transitive) To reprint as an excerpt.
examples: Articles from some magazines are offprinted from other magazines.

present participle of offprint

third-person singular simple present indicative form of offprint
third-person singular simple present indicative form of off
(transitive, chiefly South Africa) To unsaddle; remove the saddle from.
(now rare) The distant part of a view, garden etc.; the background.
refuse removed from something by scouring
(figuratively) An outcast, a pariah.
plural of offscouring
Existing or happening outside the frame of the cinema or television screen
Outside the frame of the cinema or television screen
Refuse; scum.
(obsolete) Vile; outcast.
examples: the offscum rascals of men

senses.sense: Anything that acts as counterbalance; a compensating equivalent.
examples: Today's victory was an offset to yesterday's defeat.

senses.sense: (international trade) A form of countertrade arrangement, in which the seller agrees to purchase within a set time frame products of a certain value from the buying country. This kind of agreement may be used in large international public sector contracts such as arms sales.
(c. 1555) A time at which something begins; outset.
(printing, often attributive) The offset printing process, in which ink is carried from a metal plate to a rubber blanket and from there to the printing surface.
examples: offset lithographs
offset process

senses.sense: (programming) The difference between a target memory address and a base address.
examples: An array of bytes uses its index as the offset, of words a multiple thereof.

senses.sense: (signal analysis) The displacement between the base level of a measurement and the signal's real base level.
examples: The raw signal data was subjected to a baseline correction process to subtract the sensor's offset and drift variations.

senses.sense: The distance by which one thing is out of alignment with another.
examples: There is a small offset between the switch and the indicator which some users found confusing.

senses.sense: (surveying) A short distance measured at right angles from a line actually run to some point in an irregular boundary, or to some object.
An abrupt bend in an object, such as a rod, by which one part is turned aside out of line, but nearly parallel, with the rest; the part thus bent aside.
(botany) A short prostrate shoot that takes root and produces a tuft of leaves, etc.
A spur from a range of hills or mountains.
(architecture) A horizontal ledge on the face of a wall, formed by a diminution of its thickness, or by the weathering or upper surface of a part built out from it; a set-off.
(architecture) A terrace on a hillside.

away from or off from the general locations and area where a movie’s, a film‘s, or a video’s scenery is arranged to be filmed or from those places for actors, assorted crew, director, producers which are typically not filmed.
(transitive) To counteract or compensate for, by applying a change in the opposite direction.
examples: I'll offset the time difference locally.
to offset one charge against another

senses.sense: (transitive) To place out of line.
(transitive) To form an offset in (a wall, rod, pipe, etc.).
Away from or off from the set of a movie, film, video, or play.
Away from or off from the set of a movie, film, video, or play.
plural of offset
third-person singular simple present indicative form of offset
present participle of offset
The act of offsetting
An amount offset
Something which shoots off or separates from a main stem or branch of a plant.
examples: the offshoots of a tree

senses.sense: Somethng which develops from something else.
examples: an offshoot of a criminal organization

senses.sense: plural of offshoot
Moving away from the shore.
Located in the sea away from the coast.
examples: an offshore oil rig

senses.sense: Located in another country, especially one having beneficial tax laws or labor costs.
Away from the shore.
At some distance from the shore.
To move industrial production from one region to another or from one country to another, usually seeking lower business costs, like labor.
An area or or portion of sea away from the shore.
An island, outcrop, or other land away from shore.
Something or someone in, from, or associated with another country.
(sports) In an illegal position ahead of the ball, puck, etc.
(by extension, slang) out of bounds.
(US) To the side of the road, past the curb and sidewalk.
examples: an offside diner

senses.sense: (bridge) Unfavourably located, from the point of view of the player taking a finesse.
To the side of a boat, opposite the primary side on which one paddles.
(sports) An offside play.
(British, AU) The side of a road vehicle furthest from the kerb: the right side if one drives on the left of the road.
examples: My offside wing mirror got snapped off.

senses.sense: The right-hand side of a working animal such as a horse or bullock, especially when in harness.
(British, of a canal) The side opposite the towpath.
(Australia, New Zealand, informal) A partner, assistant, or deputy.
A person's daughter or son; a person's child.
Any of a person's descendants, including of further generations.
An animal or plant's progeny or young.
(figuratively) Anything produced; the result of an entity's efforts.
examples: Artists often treasure their works as their immortal offspring.

senses.sense: (computing) A process launched by another process.
plural of offspring
Of or relating to that part of a stage not visible to the audience.
Of or relating to the private life of a celebrity.
Taking place offstage (as above)
(transitive) To relegate (part of a play) to the offstage area, rather than showing it to the audience.
(obsolete) To take off; take away.
A point or channel of drainage or off-flow; offlet.
(mining) The removal of oil (or an industrial chemical) from a storage facility.
An act of taking off; specifically, the taking away or purchase of goods.
Something taken off; a deduction.
Alternative spelling of off-track
Obsolete form of obfuscate.
Obsolete form of obfuscation.
An Igbo staff of authority.
(chiefly poetic, dialectal, and in combination) often; frequently; not rarely
examples: An oft-told tale

senses.sense: Frequently; many times.
examples: I often walk to work when the weather is nice.
I've been going to the movies more often since a new theatre opened near me.

senses.sense: (archaic) Frequent.
comparative form of often: more often
(dated) superlative form of often: most often
(rare) The quality of happening often; frequency.

(chiefly US, rare) (elsewhere, archaic) Synonym of frequent
(chiefly US) (elsewhere, archaic) Frequently; often

(mostly poetic, dialect) Most often (superlative form of oft: most oft)
